author: Jeff Neukom
title: Google Releases New Content Filtering Tool
text:
Google Releases New Content Filtering Tool "Demonstrably inaccurate information ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
In an effort to reduce internet content that users may find offensive or unsettling, Google has added a new category to allow users to flag articles and content they do not wish to see. 
The new category, “upsetting-offensive,” is now part of Google’s comprehensive, 160-page content guidelines, allowing users to notify Google’s review teams if they stumble across content they deem unacceptable or undesirable. 
For example, content with racial slurs or “extremely offensive terminology” could now get flagged as such. Advertisement - story continues below Google Claims ‘Technical Bug’ To Blame For Leaving Trump Off List Of Presidential Candidates 
While the tool itself is a new development, most — if not all — popular search engines in some way or another have protocols in place to restrict certain content. 
For example, Google’s autocomplete feature, having analyzed and mined what millions of other users have already searched for and clicked on, offers suggestions based on even a single keystroke entry, but it excludes certain terms and inputs. 
“We exclude a narrow class of search queries related to pornography, violence, hate speech, and copyright infringement,” says Google’s autocomplete FAQ. Advertisement - story continues below 
Bing, one of Google’s largest rivals, employs similar content restriction, making sure to “filter spam” as well as to “detect adult or offensive content,” according to its blog. 
In regards to Google’s new tool, if a user flags an article or other piece of content, the search results themselves are not directly affected, though Google says doing so will help the search engine rank better content higher. 
Google has long regulated content through use of review teams, comprised of roughly 10,000 contractors known as “quality raters,” who sift through numerous websites to label objectionable items such as pornography. 
While fake news has been a popular topic of late, fueled at least in part by President Trump’s resistance with the mainstream media, Paul Haahr, one of Google’s senior engineers who is involved with search quality, said the company will not use “fake news” as a parameter.
